Name: Vase with false decoration
Description: This wooden jar, part of the Hilton Price collection, probably comes from a tomb at Gebelein. It is ornamented with a decoration imitating a red stone with white marks. This type of vase belongs to a family of receptacles of diverse forms which served to contain oils and unguents. Generally made in hard stone, they were also fashioned from wood and terracotta, thus receiving a ficticious and symbolic character. They are practically always found in a funerary context. This examples bears, at mid-belly, an inscription mentioning the title and the name of the owner.
